WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. Albert Houghtaling
Address 5345 South
Birthplace Iowa, U.S.A. - 1884

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1910
Where did you set up housekeeping? Miletown, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? I attended Iowa
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4-6 in winter from 12 to 24 during the summer
How far was it to your nearest store? 4 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once or twice a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, potatoes, sugar, dried apples, dried beans, flour, flour, canned tomatoes, macaroni, corned beef, canned salmon, dry beans, salted fish.

In what quantities did you buy it? As much as a ton at a time

12. WATER SUPPLY

When we first came to Canada the water was terrible, we had a well but it was a dirty water, our house was 6 miles in a can with one horse, buggy, and then we have used water from dugouts and cisterns. How we live in a modern house with water system but yet it is the only thing filled from a muddy brook with water system.
12. WATER SUPPLY

Was there any shortage which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

When we first came to Canada the water was terrible, we had a well but I was afraid to drink it and have drunk water 4 miles in a car until one house, by my grace, had a well. Then we have used water from dugouts and cisterns. Now we live in a modern house with water system, but yet it is the only thing that has been a bother.

No we always had food but in the 30s we did have to do a lot of planning and having we made our old clothes and milk cream, butter + eggs, dairied chickens etc. and bought our food.

We earned wool through 1946 and made lovely warm comforters because we were constantly short of fuel and our house was cold.

20. Mention any new handling differences in the materials used today.

21. What did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of making them at home? (Give as many details as possible.)

I still can make my own fresh, tender, smooth, healthy food using flour, sugar, salt, eggs, milk, and vegetables. I can also make my own meat and poultry. But we do not need meat in other countries as much as we do here. We cut up to fry and dry, and then add salted ready-to-eat meat.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and preparing foods in other parts of the country. Include the names of the places or people who helped you.

We always bought in large quantities and had a cool, clean place to store our food during the harvest season. But it was hard to keep it from freezing in the winter. We often had frozen tomatoes, and we did not know how to find them to produce enough for the winter. Remember our town was very small.

23. How many miles would a horse ride at 11 o'clock?

It might be five hours away from Paulding.
In the early days, a housewife did a lot more work in order to feed a family. She had all our food, cooked, canned, and preserved what we could get hold of, how much flour, sugar, butter, and other things.

When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of making them at home?

I still can much of my own fresh and canned vegetables, fruits, and other things. I make my own bread and preserves. We also have meat in the freezer, but we do not need to buy and depend on canned goods or other stuff.

Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and storing foods. In other words, during pioneer days in Southern Indiana, Indiana Territory, and other places, tell us about quality, methods of preservation, prices, etc., etc.

We always bought in large quantities and had a cool storage place for food during the harvest season. But it was hard to keep it from freezing in the winter. We often canned peaches, tomatoes, and other things, and we did not know how to find the best way to preserve them for the winter. If necessary, we would go hungry for weeks if sandwiches that were found near a house 4 miles at 11 o'clock at night to get some food.
